MELK Is a Novel Interactor of NIPP1—A yeast two-hybrid screening of a HeLa cell library with the N-terminal third of NIPP1 (residues 1–142) as bait yielded, in addition to clones encoding CDC5L (11Boudrez A. Beullens M. Groenen P. Van Eynde A. Vulsteke V. Jagiello I. Murray M. Krainer A.R. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25411-25417Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar) and SAP155 fragments (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), 16 prey clones that all encoded the C-terminal half of the poorly characterized protein kinase MELK (for maternal embryonic leucine zipper kinase) (14Heyer B.S. Kochanowski H. Solter D. Dev. Dyn. 1999; 215: 344-351Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar) (Fig. 1). Compared with this MELK fragment, the full-length protein was a much better interactor with NIPP1 in two-hybrid assays (Fig. 1B). However, a deletion mutant of MELK, lacking the TP-rich domain, did not interact with NIPP1-(1–142). The MELK-NIPP1 interaction was lost by mutation (S68A/R69A/V70A/H71A) of the phosphate-binding loop of the FHA domain of NIPP1 (Fig. 1B), indicating that MELK interacted with the FHA domain of NIPP1 via a phosphorylated residue(s). Fig. 1C shows that all bait and prey proteins were well expressed, further validating the two-hybrid data. We have previously demonstrated that CDC5L (11Boudrez A. Beullens M. Groenen P. Van Eynde A. Vulsteke V. Jagiello I. Murray M. Krainer A.R. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 25411-25417Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar) and SAP155 (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar) bind to the FHA domain of NIPP1 via threonine-phosphorylated TP dipeptide motifs. The fragment of MELK that binds to NIPP1 also contains numerous TP motifs (Fig. 1A). To examine whether one or several of these TP motifs are involved in the interaction with NIPP1 we performed two-hybrid assays after mutation (Thr to Ala) of each of the 10 TP motifs in the NIPP1-interaction domain of MELK (Fig. 2). All mutants were expressed well (Fig. 2B). However, four mutants showed a significantly reduced interaction with NIPP1 in the two-hybrid assays. The T478A mutant in particular was severely impaired in binding NIPP1. These data implicate some TP motifs of MELK, in particular the TP motif comprising Thr-478 and Pro-479, in the interaction with NIPP1. Interaction of Purified Components—To further explore whether MELK and NIPP1 interact directly and in a phosphorylation-dependent manner, we expressed the NIPP1-interacting C-terminal domain of MELK (residues 326–651) as a His-tagged protein in bacteria. Purified recombinant MELK-(326–651) did not sediment with GST-tagged NIPP1-(1–142) (Fig. 3). However, we noted that a preincubation of MELK-(326–651) with a HeLa cell nuclear extract in the presence of Mg-ATP enabled its interaction with GST-NIPP1-(1–142). Importantly, a co-sedimentation with GST-NIPP1-(1–142) was not seen after a preincubation of the T478A mutant with nuclear extracts under phosphorylation conditions (Fig. 3). The above data showed that MELK interacts directly with the FHA domain of NIPP1 and that this interaction is largely mediated by phosphorylated Thr-478. In further agreement with this interpretation, we found that the synthetic phosphopeptide MELK-(470–487)-phospho-Thr-478 could be used as a competitor to disrupt the interaction between GST-NIPP1-(1–142) and its FHA ligand, CDC5L, in nuclear extracts (Fig. 3B). By contrast, the nonphosphorylated MELK peptide did not have this effect. MELK Is an Inhibitor of Spliceosome Assembly—To explore the role of the NIPP1-MELK interaction, we prepared purified bacterially expressed NIPP1 and baculovirus-expressed MELK. In addition to wild-type MELK we generated a NIPP1-binding mutant (MELK-T478A) as well as a kinase-dead mutant (MELK-D150A). The latter is mutated in the essential”DFG“triplet in kinase subdomain VII, which is required for the binding of Mg-ATP (15Hanks S.K. Hunter T. FASEB J. 1995; 9: 576-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (2295) Google Scholar). All three proteins were expressed in Sf9 insect cells as insoluble inclusion bodies and were inactive. However, the inclusion bodies could be dissolved in 6 m guanidinium chloride, and MELK could be renatured by extensive and rapid dilution with a buffer containing Mn2+, as described previously for the catalytic subunit of PP1 (13Berndt N. Cohen P T.W. Eur. J. Biochem. 1990; 190: 291-297Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The renatured wild-type MELK was capable of phosphorylating exogenous substrates such as myelin basic protein (Fig. 4) as well as histones H1, 2A, and 3 (not shown). In addition, autophosphorylation of MELK was detected (Fig. 4). As expected, the D150A mutant was inactive, but surprisingly, at equal protein concentrations the T478A mutant was much more active than the wild-type protein. Recombinant NIPP1 did not affect the ability of baculovirus-expressed MELK to autophosphorylate or to phosphorylate myelin basic protein (not shown). Because NIPP1 is an established pre-mRNA splicing factor, we subsequently examined whether the interactor MELK also has a role in pre-mRNA splicing. Fig. 5A shows that the addition of 1 μm wild-type MELK completely blocked the splicing of a fragment of β-globin pre-mRNA by HeLa cell nuclear extracts. Interestingly, the kinase-dead mutant of MELK had the same effect, indicating that the splicing inhibition was independent of phosphorylation by MELK. On the other hand, no splicing inhibition was seen with the NIPP1-binding mutant, indicating a mediatory role for NIPP1. No splicing intermediates were detected in the presence of MELK or MELK-D150A, suggesting that MELK interfered with spliceosome assembly rather than with splicing catalysis per se. In further agreement with this conclusion we found that MELK did not affect pre-mRNA splicing when added after spliceosome assembly, i.e. after a preincubation of the splicing extracts for 20 min (not shown). Spliceosome assembly occurs stepwise (Complex E → Complex A → Complex B → Complex C) and involves the recruitment of small nuclear ribonucleoproteins and splicing factors as well as intraspliceosomal rearrangements (16Reed R. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2000; 12: 340-345Crossref PubMed Scopus (188) Google Scholar). Native gel electrophoresis revealed that MELK (Fig. 5B) and MELK-D150A (not shown) blocked an early step of spliceosome assembly, i.e. a step before the assembly of the A-complex. This implies that MELK inhibits either the assembly of the E-complex or the transition from the E-complex to the A-complex. The MELK-NIPP1 Interaction Is Increased during Mitosis— The previous data suggested that the MELK-NIPP1 interaction results in an inhibition of pre-mRNA splicing. One of the cellular processes associated with a complete block of pre-mRNA splicing is mitosis. Because MELK appears to be maximally phosphorylated during mitosis (17Blot J. Chartrain I. Roghi C. Philippe M. Tassan J.-P. Dev. Biol. 2002; 241: 327-338Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 18Davezac N. Baldin V. Blot J. Ducommon B. Tassan J.-P. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 7630-7641Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar) and only interacts with NIPP1 when phosphorylated (this study), we reasoned that the MELK-NIPP1 interaction might be increased during mitosis. To explore this hypothesis, we co-expressed GST-tagged NIPP1 and FLAG-tagged MELK in COS-1 cells. The amount of MELK that co-precipitated with GST-NIPP1 from the cell lysates was indeed dramatically increased when the cells were blocked in mitosis by the addition of either colcemid (Fig. 6A) or nocodazole (not shown) at 20–24 h before cell lysis; this increase could not be explained by different expression levels of the GST-NIPP1 or FLAG-MELK fusions (Fig. 6, B and C). The same results were obtained with the kinase-dead mutant MELK-D150A, showing that MELK kinase activity is not required for the phosphorylation of MELK on a site(s) that mediates its interaction with NIPP1. Importantly, MELK-T478A was a weak interactor of NIPP1 in cell lysates from both asynchronized and mitotically arrested cells, in accordance with our two-hybrid (Fig. 1) and GST pull-down experiments (Fig. 3). MELK-(1–266), which lacks the NIPP1 interaction site but contains the kinase catalytic domain (Fig. 1A), did not bind to NIPP1 in either condition. The above results demonstrated that NIPP1 and MELK interact with each other in vivo and that their interaction is considerably increased during mitosis, when pre-mRNA splicing is abolished. The MELK-NIPP1 Interaction—We have shown here that MELK is an interactor of the FHA domain of NIPP1 and that this interaction involves the binding of a threonine-phosphorylated TP motif to the phosphate binding loop of the FHA domain. The TP motif of MELK that appears to be most critical for the interaction with NIPP1 in yeast (Fig. 2), in COS-1 cells (Fig. 6), and in vitro with recombinant proteins (Fig. 3) comprises Thr-478 and Pro-479. However, as we have previously already demonstrated for SAP155 (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), it is possible that other TP motifs of MELK, when phosphorylated, can also mediate binding to NIPP1. It will therefore be important to identify the protein kinase(s) that phosphorylates the TP motifs of MELK and to examine whether the activation of this kinase(s) results in an increased interaction with NIPP1. Interestingly, all three established ligands of the FHA domain of NIPP1, i.e. CDC5L (19Stukenberg P.T. Lustig K.D. McGarry T.J. King R.W. Kuang J. Kirschner M.W. Curr. Biol. 1997; 7: 338-348Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar), SAP155 (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar), and MELK (17Blot J. Chartrain I. Roghi C. Philippe M. Tassan J.-P. Dev. Biol. 2002; 241: 327-338Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 18Davezac N. Baldin V. Blot J. Ducommon B. Tassan J.-P. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 7630-7641Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar), are hyperphosphorylated during mitosis, and at least in the case of SAP155 (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar) and MELK (this work), this phosphorylation includes threonine residues that bind directly to the FHA domain of NIPP1. Thus, one or more mitotic kinases promote the interaction between the splicing factor NIPP1 and its FHA ligands, providing a novel link between cell cycle progression and pre-mRNA processing. Additional evidence for such a link comes from observations that the overexpression of the splicing factor CDC5L shortens the G2 phase (20Bernstein H.S. Coughlin S.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 4666-4671Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar), whereas the overexpression of MELK is associated with an accumulation of cells in G2/M (18Davezac N. Baldin V. Blot J. Ducommon B. Tassan J.-P. Oncogene. 2002; 21: 7630-7641Crossref PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). It will be interesting to delineate the contribution of NIPP1 to these effects of CDC5L and MELK. Our preliminary data suggest that the overexpression of MELK-T478A also causes a G2/M block (not illustrated), indicating that this effect of MELK does not depend on the recruitment of NIPP1. Along the same lines, it will be important to investigate whether the increased SAP155-NIPP1 and MELK-NIPP1 interactions contribute to the splicing arrest during mitosis or rather are implicated in the re-initiation of splicing in the early G1 phase. It should be pointed out that other splicing factors have also been implicated in connecting RNA splicing with cell cycle progression (21Blencowe B.J. Curr. Biol. 2003; 13: R149-R151Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). For example, it has recently been demonstrated that the SR protein SRp38 is required for splicing repression during mitosis (22Shin C. Manley J.L. Cell. 2003; 111: 407-417Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (167) Google Scholar). The mitotic kinase that phosphorylates MELK on Thr-478 is unlikely to be MELK itself, since a kinase-dead mutant still showed an increased interaction with NIPP1 during mitosis (Fig. 6). We also found that recombinant MELK is not an in vitro substrate for cyclin-B/Cdk1 (not shown), indicating that Thr-478 is phosphorylated by a distinct mitotic kinase. It should also be pointed out that the increased phosphorylation of MELK on Thr-478 during mitosis is not necessarily the result of an increased MEL kinase kinase activity but could also be accounted for by a reduced MELK phosphatase activity. NIPP1 and Pre-mRNA Splicing—The inhibition of spliceosome assembly by MELK does not require a functional catalytic site but depends on Thr-478 (Fig. 5), which is essential for the binding of NIPP1. One possible explanation for this inhibition of spliceosome assembly is that MELK competes with other splicing factors for binding to the FHA domain and thereby prevents the recruitment of NIPP1 to the spliceosomes. We have previously demonstrated that the C-terminal third of NIPP1 is required for a late step (B → C transition) of spliceosome assembly and that the formation of the B-complex proceeds normally in the presence of NIPP1-(1–142) (8Beullens M. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19855-19860Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Our observation that wild-type MELK, but not the NIPP1-binding mutant, blocks an early step of spliceosome assembly (Fig. 5) could therefore suggest that NIPP1-(1–142) is needed for an early step of spliceosome assembly. Inhibition of spliceosome assembly by MELK in splicing extracts did not require a functional catalytic domain. However, this does not rule out the possibility that MELK also affects pre-mRNA processing in vivo by protein phosphorylation. For example, we have noted that CDC5L and SAP155, as well as NIPP1, are in vitro substrates for phosphorylation by MELK, which could contribute to the regulation of splicing by MELK. The interaction of the FHA domain of NIPP1 with its ligands is correlated with both splicing catalysis and splicing arrest. On the one hand, a functional FHA domain is required for spliceosome assembly (8Beullens M. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 19855-19860Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar), and ligands of the FHA domain, such as MELK, competitively block spliceosome assembly (Fig. 5). On the other hand, the FHA domain of NIPP1 is also required for the targeting of NIPP1 to the nuclear storage sites of splicing factors (10Jagiello I. Van Eynde A. Vulsteke V. Beullens M. Boudrez A. Keppens S. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Cell Sci. 2000; 113: 3761-3764Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and NIPP1 shows an increased interaction with SAP155 (12Boudrez A. Beullens M. Waelkens E. Stalmans W. Bollen M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 31834-31841Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar) and MELK (Fig. 6) during mitosis, when splicing is arrested. One explanation for these paradoxical findings is that the binding of NIPP1 to some FHA ligands is associated with splicing arrest, whereas the association with other ligands promotes spliceosome assembly. Alternatively, the FHA-mediated targeting of NIPP1 to the nuclear speckles during interphase and to the mitotic storage sites of splicing factors serves as a “priming” mechanism that enables a rapid resumption of pre-mRNA splicing by the recruitment of pre-assembled complexes of splicing factors during spliceosome assembly. Nevertheless, the tight regulation of the interaction between NIPP1 and its ligands by reversible phosphorylation and the fact that NIPP1 is associated with both a protein kinase (MELK) and a protein phosphatase (PP1) suggest a key “integrator” function for NIPP1 in signal transduction to splicing. Regulation of MELK—Based on the structural conservation of its catalytic domain (23Manning G. Whyte D.B. Martinez R. Hunter T. Sudarsanam S. Science. 2002; 398: 1912-1943Crossref Scopus (6312) Google Scholar), MELK belongs to the family of CAMK-like protein kinases that also includes protein kinases MARK (24Drewes G. Ebneth A. Preuss U. Mandelkow E.-M. Mandelkow E. Cell. 1997; 89: 297-308Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (717) Google Scholar), PASK (25Rutter J. Michnoff C.H. Harper S.M. Gardner K.H. McKnight S.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 8991-8996Crossref PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar), as well as the AMP-activated protein kinases (26Hardie D.G. Carling D. Carlson M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 821-855Crossref PubMed Scopus (1281) Google Scholar). It is currently not known how the activity of MELK is controlled but this is likely to be complex. MELK is capable of autophosphorylation (Fig. 4), but it is not yet clear whether this also affects its activity. Thr-167 of MELK corresponds to a phosphorylatable Thr within the activation loop of related protein kinases (26Hardie D.G. Carling D. Carlson M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1998; 67: 821-855Crossref PubMed Scopus (1281) Google Scholar, 27Hawley S.A. Boudeau J. Reid J.L. Mustard K.J. Udd L. Makela T.P. Alessi D.R. Hardie D.G. J. Biol. 2003; 2: 28Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For example, activation of the AMP-activated kinase requires phosphorylation of this Thr in the activation loop by the tumor suppressor LKB1 (27Hawley S.A. Boudeau J. Reid J.L. Mustard K.J. Udd L. Makela T.P. Alessi D.R. Hardie D.G. J. Biol. 2003; 2: 28Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). It also seems likely that the large C-terminal domain of MELK, which includes the TP-rich NIPP1-binding domain, has a regulatory function. Our preliminary data indicate that this domain is inhibitory because the T478A mutant is more active than wild-type MELK (Fig. 3) and because the recombinant C-terminal half of MELK is a strong inhibitor of the kinase activity of MELK. 2V. Vulsteke, M. Beullens, A. Boudrez, S. Keppens, A. Van Eynde, W. Stalmans, and M. Bollen, unpublished data. A further exploration of the mechanisms that control the activity of MELK will be essential to elucidate the signaling pathways that impinge on MELK and its interactor NIPP1. We thank Valere Feytons, Annemie Hoogmartens, and Nicole Sente for expert technical assistance.

The oviduct-derived embryotrophic factor, ETF-3, enhances the development of trophectoderm and the hatching process of treated embryos. Monoclonal anti-ETF-3 antibody that abolishes the embryotrophic activity of ETF-3 recognized a 115-kDa protein from the conditioned medium of immortalized human oviductal cells. Mass spectrometry analysis showed that the protein was complement C3. Western blot analysis using an antibody against C3 confirmed the cross-reactivities between anti-C3 antibody with ETF-3 and anti-ETF-3 antibody with C3 and its derivatives, C3b and iC3b. Both derivatives, but not C3, were embryotrophic. iC3b was most efficient in enhancing the development of blastocysts with larger size and higher hatching rate, consistent with the previous reported embryotrophic activity of ETF-3. Embryos treated with iC3b contained iC3b immunoreactivity. The oviductal epithelium produced C3 as evidenced by the presence of C3 immunoreactivity and mRNA in the human oviduct and cultured oviductal cells. Cyclical changes in the expression of C3 immunoreactivity and mRNA were also found in the mouse oviduct with the highest expression at the estrus stage. Molecules involving in the conversion of C3b to iC3b and binding of iC3b were present in the human oviduct (factor I) and mouse preimplantation embryo (Crry and CR3), respectively. In conclusion, the present data showed that the oviduct produced C3/C3b, which was converted to iC3b to stimulate embryo development. The oviduct-derived embryotrophic factor, ETF-3, enhances the development of trophectoderm and the hatching process of treated embryos. Monoclonal anti-ETF-3 antibody that abolishes the embryotrophic activity of ETF-3 recognized a 115-kDa protein from the conditioned medium of immortalized human oviductal cells. Mass spectrometry analysis showed that the protein was complement C3. Western blot analysis using an antibody against C3 confirmed the cross-reactivities between anti-C3 antibody with ETF-3 and anti-ETF-3 antibody with C3 and its derivatives, C3b and iC3b. Both derivatives, but not C3, were embryotrophic. iC3b was most efficient in enhancing the development of blastocysts with larger size and higher hatching rate, consistent with the previous reported embryotrophic activity of ETF-3. Embryos treated with iC3b contained iC3b immunoreactivity. The oviductal epithelium produced C3 as evidenced by the presence of C3 immunoreactivity and mRNA in the human oviduct and cultured oviductal cells. Cyclical changes in the expression of C3 immunoreactivity and mRNA were also found in the mouse oviduct with the highest expression at the estrus stage. Molecules involving in the conversion of C3b to iC3b and binding of iC3b were present in the human oviduct (factor I) and mouse preimplantation embryo (Crry and CR3), respectively. In conclusion, the present data showed that the oviduct produced C3/C3b, which was converted to iC3b to stimulate embryo development. Research is ongoing to optimize the embryo culture condition in human in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer programs. A large proportion of time when embryos are cultured in vitro is when they should be developing in the oviduct in vivo. Oviductal microenvironment is generally accepted to provide the best support to early embryo development. Oviductal cell coculture, the culture of embryo with oviductal cells, has been shown to improve the success rate in prospective randomized control clinical trials (1Yeung W.S.B. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Reprod. Med. Rev. 2002; 10: 21-44Crossref Scopus (24) Google Scholar). In vitro experiments show that human oviductal cell coculture enhances the ability of the embryo at blastocyst stage to escape from its outer shell, zona pellucida, in a process known as hatching. Coculture also reduces the fragmentation rate of human embryos (2Bongso A. Soon-Chye N. Sathananthan H. Lian N.P. Rauff M. Ratnam S. Hum. Reprod. 1989; 4: 706-713Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar, 3Yeung W.S. Ho P.C. Lau E.Y. Chan S.T. Hum. Reprod. 1992; 7: 1144-1149Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar) and increases the blastulation rate and total cell count per blastocyst of mouse embryos (4Liu L.P. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Hum. Reprod. 1995; 10: 2781-2786Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar). Despite the success of coculture, it is not commonly used in in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer programs because of the complexity in its implementation as a service. Therefore, sequential culture, the use of different media for culturing embryos at different stages of development, is currently the method of choice for improving the outcome of the human in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer program (5Gardner D.K. Schoolcraft W.B. Wagley L. Schlenker T. Stevens J. Hesla J. Hum. Reprod. 1998; 13: 3434-3440Crossref PubMed Scopus (625) Google Scholar). However, the culture condition in sequential culture systems is still suboptimal as the development of human embryos in these systems can be further improved by supplementation of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (6Sjoblom C. Wikland M. Robertson S.A. Hum. Reprod. 1999; 14: 3069-3076Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar), a cytokine with peak expression during the preimplantation period in the human fallopian tube (7Zhao Y. Chegini N. J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab. 1994; 79: 662-665Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar). Our unpublished data 1J. S. Xu and W. S. B. Yeung, unpublished results. 1J. S. Xu and W. S. B. Yeung, unpublished results. also show that mouse blastocysts after human oviductal cell coculture in G1.2/G2.2, the most commonly used sequential culture system, have better trophectoderm development and therefore hatch more often than those cultured in sequential medium alone. Thus, the beneficial effect of coculture and sequential culture on embryo development can be merged if the embryotrophic factors from the cocultured cells are known and are supplemented to the sequential culture system. Human oviductal cells improve the development of mouse embryos in vitro by the production of factors like cytokines and other factors with unknown identities (1Yeung W.S.B. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Reprod. Med. Rev. 2002; 10: 21-44Crossref Scopus (24) Google Scholar). We have purified three embryotrophic fractions termed ETF-1, ETF-2, and ETF-3 from human oviductal cell conditioned medium by various liquid chromatographies (4Liu L.P. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Hum. Reprod. 1995; 10: 2781-2786Crossref PubMed Scopus (59) Google Scholar, 8Liu L.P. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Hum. Reprod. 1998; 13: 1613-1619Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). Whereas ETF-1 and ETF-2 preferentially stimulate the development of inner cell mass, ETF-3 enhances the development of trophectoderm, which leads to an increase in the blastocyst size, hatching, and attachment of the hatched blastocyst (9Xu J.S. Cheung T.M. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2001; 65: 1481-1488Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). ETF-3 is most abundant among the three ETFs (8Liu L.P. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Hum. Reprod. 1998; 13: 1613-1619Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). In this paper, we report the use of matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF) 2The abbreviations used are: MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; MS, mass spectrometry; RT, reverse transcription. 2The abbreviations used are: MALDI-TOF, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization time-of-flight; MS, mass spectrometry; RT, reverse transcription. mass spectrometry (MS) (10He Q.Y. Chiu J.F. J. Cell. Biochem. 2003; 89: 868-886Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar) and Western blot to identify ETF-3 as a mixture containing complement protein 3 (C3) and its derivative, C3b. We demonstrate that the oviductal epithelium produces the complement protein in a cyclical manner. In the classical immune cascade, C3 is cleaved to C3b and C3a when being activated. C3b is further cleaved to iC3b during inactivation by factor I in the presence of cofactors, such as membrane cofactor protein (MCP; CD46). In mice, the rodent-restricted transmembrane C3 convertase inhibitor, Crry, served the function of MCP and DAF (11Molina H. Cell Mol. Life Sci. 2002; 59: 220-229Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). In this paper, we report the presence of these molecules in the oviduct/embryo, suggesting that C3b is converted to iC3b, which is the biologically active embryotrophic molecule of ETF-3. Production of Anti-ETF-3 Antibody—Purified ETF-3 isolated from oviductal cell conditioned medium was used to generate anti-ETF-3 monoclonal antibodies. Screening was performed by enzyme immunoassay 10–12 days after fusion (12Luk J.M. Nnalue N.A. Lindberg A.A. J. Immunol. Methods. 1990; 129: 243-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Positive hybridomas were cloned and used to produce antibodies in serum-free medium. Anti-ETF-3 monoclonal antibody clone-14 (ETF3-C14) was purified by affinity chromatography using HiTrap Protein G-Sepharose (Amersham Biosciences) and concentrated by the Centricon-30 concentrator (Amicon, Beverly, CA). The immunoreactivity of the antibody was confirmed by Western blot analysis of three different batches of ETF-3. Protein G Purification of ETF-3—The conditioned medium derived from the immortalized oviductal cells, OE-E6/E7 (13Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Wang Y.L. Tsao S.W. Yeung W.S. Mol. Reprod. Dev. 2001; 59: 400-409Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar), was passed through a concanavalin A affinity column using a fast performance liquid chromatographic system (Amersham Biosciences). Two hundred micrograms of ETF3-C14 was incubated overnight with the dialyzed concanavalin A eluate. The mixture was then passed through a 5-ml HiTrap Protein G column (Amersham Biosciences). The bound immunocomplex was eluted, and the purity was confirmed by Western blot analysis using ETF3-C14 (1:100) and anti-mouse IgG antiserum conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (1:5000). The signal was visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence according to the manufacturer's recommendation (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA). Two-dimensional Gel Electrophoresis—The electrophoresis was carried out as described previously (14He Q.Y. Lau G.K. Zhou Y. Yuen S.T. Lin M.C. Kung H.F. Chiu J.F. Proteomics. 2003; 3: 666-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). Ten micrograms of ETF3-C14 affinity-purified ETF-3 was loaded onto a 13-cm IPG strip (pH 3–10). The first dimension was run on an Ettan IPGphor isoelectric Focusing System (Amersham Biosciences), followed by the second dimension SDS electrophoresis in the Hoefer SE 600 system. The gel was then silver-stained. MALDI-TOF Peptide Mass Fingerprint Analysis—The 115-kDa protein band from one-dimensional SDS-PAGE (Coomassie Blue-stained) was used for mass spectrometry analysis. In-gel digestion was performed as reported elsewhere (14He Q.Y. Lau G.K. Zhou Y. Yuen S.T. Lin M.C. Kung H.F. Chiu J.F. Proteomics. 2003; 3: 666-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar), and the digest was analyzed in a Voyager-DE STR MALDI-TOF mass spectrometer (PerSeptive Biosystems, Framingham, MA). The mass spectrum was obtained in the delayed extraction mode using an accelerating voltage of 20 kV and a 175-ns delay. Trypsin autolytic fragment peaks of 906.5049, 1153.5741, and 2163.0570 were used for internal calibration. Data base searching was performed with ProteinProspector MS-Fit (available on the World Wide Web at prospector.ucsf.edu) (14He Q.Y. Lau G.K. Zhou Y. Yuen S.T. Lin M.C. Kung H.F. Chiu J.F. Proteomics. 2003; 3: 666-674Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). Western Blot Analysis Using Anti-C3 and ETF3-C14 Antibody—To confirm that ETF-3 secreted from OE-E6/E7 cells was C3 and that the ETF3-C14 recognized C3, C3b, and iC3b from human serum (Calbiochem), the concanavalin A-eluted fraction (partially purified) and ETF-3 derived from OE-E6/E7 were separated by SDS-PAGE. Western blot analysis was performed using goat anti-human C3 antibody (1: 20,000; Calbiochem) or ETF3-C14 (1:100). The protein bands in the blot were observed with Coomassie Blue staining. Embryotrophic Activity of C3 Derivatives—Embryo culture was performed as described (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The zygotes were cultured in CZB medium (16Chatot C.L. Ziomek C.A. Bavister B.D. Lewis J.L. Torres I. J. Reprod. Fertil. 1989; 86: 679-688Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) alone or CZB supplemented with 10 μg/ml of C3, C3b, and iC3b for the first 48 h. They were then transferred to CZB containing 5 mm glucose and appropriate supplementation of C3 or its derivatives. The percentages of embryos reaching fully expanded blastocyst and hatching blastocyst were recorded at ∼120 and 144 h post-human chorionic gonadotropin, respectively. The image of each expanded blastocyst was captured with a phase-contrast inverted microscope. The area of the expanded blastocyst in the images was determined using the MetaMorph imaging system (version 3.51; Universal Imaging Corp., West Chester, PA) and compared among different experimental groups. Immunohistochemical Staining—Human oviductal tissue was obtained from patients admitted for hysterectomy due to uterine fibromyoma. The Ethics Committee of the University approved the study protocol. Formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded human oviduct tissue sections were immunostained with the anti-C3 antibody (1:2000; Calbiochem) followed by fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled rabbit anti-goat IgG antibody (1:100; Zymed Laboratories Inc., San Francisco, CA). The section was counterstained with propidium iodide. The negative control sections were incubated in parallel with omission of the first antibody or with ETF-3 or iC3b preabsorbed anti-C3 antibody. The sections were observed with a confocal microscope (MRC-600; BioRad). The expression of C3 protein in OE-E6/E7 cells was also studied with the cells cultured in chamber slide (Nunc, Inc., Naperville, IL). The expression of factor I protein in the human oviduct section was studied with the same protocol using goat anti-factor I (1:2000; Calbiochem) with or without factor I preabsorption. Immunostaining of mouse blastocyst cultured with or without iC3b treatment were preformed as described (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) using anti-C3 antibody (1:2000) and fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled rabbit anti-goat IgG antibody (1:100). The stained blastocysts were examined under a confocal microscope. RT-PCR for Human C3 and Factor I Expression—Total RNAs from two primary oviductal cell samples (OE89 and OE109), OE-E6/E7 cells at passages 14, and 25, human oviductal epithelium tissue, SKOV-3, CHO-K1 cell lines, and human liver tissue were isolated using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's protocol. The quantity and quality of total RNA samples were analyzed by UV spectrophotometry. One hundred nanograms of total RNA was subjected to RT-PCR using the Access RT-PCR system (Promega, Madison, WI) according to the manufacturer's protocol using specific primers for human C3 (5′-GGTCAAGCAGGACTCCTTGT-3′ and 5′-CCCTTGTTCATGATGAGGTAG-3) and human factor I (5′-GTCTTCTGCCAGCCATGGCAGAGA-3′ and 5′-GTAATGCAGTCCACCTCACCATT-3′). C3 Protein and mRNA Expression in Mouse Oviducts in Estrous Cycle—The estrous cycle of sexually mature (6–8-week-old) MF1 female mice was determined by vaginal smear. The protein expression of C3 in their oviducts at different estrus stages was studied by immunohistochemical staining described above using polyclonal antibody against the β-chain of C3 (sc-14612; Santa Cruz Biotechnology). The antibody was omitted in the negative control. Semiquantitative RT-PCR was performed as described (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) to determine the relative changes of C3 mRNA in mouse oviducts in the estrus cycle using mouse C3-specific primers (5′-AGAAGACTGCCTGACCTTCA-3′ and 5′-TTTTCTCCCCAGAGGTCAGA-3′). The relative amount of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (5′-ACCACAGTCCATGCCATCAC-3′ and 5′-TCCACCACCCTGTTGCTGTA-3′) was used for normalization of the mRNA loading. The relative amount of amplified products was quantified by Labwork Image Acquisition and Analysis Software (UVP, Inc., Upland, CA). A minimum of four replicates of semiquantitative RT-PCR were performed. Messenger RNA Expression of Complement-binding Proteins in Mouse Embryos—In vivo developed mouse embryos at different stages of development were flushed from oviducts or uteri. mRNA of the embryos was isolated using the Dynabeads mRNA Direct kit (Dynal AS) as described (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Two-step RT-PCR was used to determine the Crry, complement receptor 3 (CD11b and CD18), and DAF mRNA transcripts in these embryos. The primers used were Crry (5′-CATCACAGCTTCCTTCTGCCA-3′, 5′-ATCGTTGCTGGTACAGTATA-3′), CD11b (5′-CAGATCAACAATGTGACCGTATGG-3′, 5′-CATCATGTCCTTGTACTGCCGC-3′), CD18 (5′-CATATGTGACGAAGGCTACCA-3′, 5′-TCTAGACTGTCCTCCACATG-3′), and DAF (5′-CAATGGGAATAATGCGAGGGGA-3′, 5′-TATTGTATCCATTCTTCTTG-3′). Data Analysis—Data were analyzed using SigmaStat software (Jandel Scientific, San Rafael, CA). The data obtained from at least three replicates were combined and analyzed by the χ2 test for the development of embryos and t test for the comparison of the significance of the areas of late blastocysts at day 5 on mouse embryo development. One-way analysis of variance followed by the Student-Newman-Keuls method were used to compare mRNA expression determined by semiquantitative RT-PCR. Differences of p < 0.05 were considered significant. Identification of ETF-3—In order to purify ETF-3 to homogeneity for identification, monoclonal antibodies against ETF-3 were raised. The antiserum of the mouse from which ETF3-C14 was raised nullified the activity of ETF-3 on blastulation and hatching of mouse embryos (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). The antiserum also bound to the epithelial cells of the human oviduct and to the blastomeres of ETF-3-treated mouse embryos (15Lee Y.L. Lee K.F. Xu J.S. Kwok K.L. Luk J.M. Lee W.M. Yeung W.S. Biol. Reprod. 2003; 68: 375-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). ETF3-C14 abolished the embryotrophic effect of ETF-3 (Fig. 1). Western blot analysis showed the presence of an additional 115-kDa protein (PG-115; Fig. 2, lane A) in ETF3-C14 affinity-purified ETF-3 immunocomplex when compared with ETF3-C14 alone (Fig. 2, lane B). In two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, the protein appeared as dots with the same size but with slightly different pI ranging from 6 to 7 (data not shown), consistent with our previous conclusion that ETF-3 was glycoprotein in nature (8Liu L.P. Chan S.T. Ho P.C. Yeung W.S. Hum. Reprod. 1998; 13: 1613-1619Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). ETF3-C14 reacted with the 115-kDa α-chain of C3 (α-115), the 106-kDa α′-chain of C3b (α′-106), and the 40-kDa α-chain of iC3b (α-40), indicating that the binding epitope of the antibody was in the α-40 fragment of C3. Anti-C3 polyclonal antibody detected the presence of C3 fragments in purified and partially purified ETF-3 (concanavalin A-bound fraction of OE-E6/E7 conditioned medium) with sizes of 115, 106, 75, and 40 kDa (Fig. 3, lanes 4 and 5, respectively).
